awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Understanding Security in the Software Development Lifecycle: A Holistic, Mixed-Methods Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
As software now pervades nearly every aspect of modern life, securing software is widely acknowledged as a critical problem. Although significant effort has gone into identifying flaws in software, as well as developing tools, libraries, and processes for detecting and mitigating these flaws during software development and maintenance, security problems remain pervasive. There has been comparatively little effort to empirically assess the effectiveness of existing tools and processes in realistic settings, and almost no effort to understand the root causes of professional developers making security errors. This lack of knowledge hinders the advancement of secure programming techniques that can effectively reduce the number of security bugs in deployed software. This research focuses on measuring and evaluating the effectiveness of particular approaches to securing software as carried out by typical developers. By combining anthropological observation of industrial development practice with experimental evaluation of tools and processes, this project will identify new or underappreciated approaches to improving software security in practice.

The research includes four interdependent approaches: anthropological observation via long-term embedding in partner industrial software development teams; conducting and analyzing results from secure-programming contests that serve as quasi-experiments; controlled lab experiments; and analysis of open-source software artifacts. The anthropological approach produces deep insights through zero-proximity observation and reflection by fieldworkers, and competitions illuminate how differences in approach (language, tools, etc.) to a substantive problem correlate (quantitatively and qualitatively) with success or failure. Both of these approaches will generate hypotheses, which can then be tested via controlled lab experiments, as well as additional field, contest, and artifact observations. This combination of approaches leverages the strength of each in order to maximize both ecological and internal validity, offering the best chance to understand the real causes of (in)secure software development and offer effective guidance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computer science researchers with training in anthropological research methods conducted fieldwork in software companies, to study the practice of secure software development. Three fieldworkers spent a combined 26 months embedded in various development teams in a software company. The researchers were assigned tasks as regular developers would be, and in their work observed practices and behaviors of the developers regarding secure coding practices. Qualitative analysis was conducted on the data collected through the fieldwork. A number of key findings were discovered in the research. First, when faced with security issues in code, developers' reactions are mostly shaped by the incentive structures in the organization. They appear to be making a calculated trade--off between the risk of breaking the software while fixing a vulnerability, and the potential liability if the vulnerability is left unfixed. This is a reality a security advocate, whether inside or outside the developer team, must accept.

Second, security professionals need to understand specific ways the software is built in a product, so they can customize secure coding solutions so developers can apply them naturally in their regular workflow. Instead of merely emphasizing that developers shall think as attackers, security professionals shall also think as developers so they understand the unique constraints in building a particular software product. This finding strongly suggests that a co-creation model provides good value for experimentation in real practice. Security advocates were more successful when the security fixes needed to be applied to new code, as opposed to old ones. It appears that co-creation works more effectively "in the moment," as opposed to retroactively trying to fix things. 

Third, our data analysis points to the applicability of the situated learning theory in explaining how developers learn in their daily practices, and how such learning dynamics drive a cycle that eventually leads to the establishment of the "preferred practices" of a community -- in this case, the software development team. When the established practices concern secure coding, this learning dynamics essentially drive the creation of a security culture within the team. Our data also indicate that such dynamics are driven by the innate nature of how people learn in a community of practice, and thus likely applicable to other companies. This could provide useful ideas for companies with similar sizes to consider experimenting the same processes as happened in this one, for the purpose of creating security culture within the development teams.

The findings from the research resonate well with both the research and practitioner community. Dissemination of the results include two publications in SOUPS, the premier venue for usable security research, and one article to appear in a special issue of Human Organization, which is a journal of the Society for Applied Anthropology and the leading peer reviewed outlet for scholarship in the applied social sciences. One of the SOUPS papers won the Distinguished Paper Award. 

The results can be used to improve secure development processes, by identifying approaches that (do not) work well, barriers to effective adoption of existing tools and techniques, and key design considerations for developing future security-enhancing techniques. By providing strong empirical evidence, the work can help convince companies to adopt security practices that are efficient and effective. Even small improvements in secure development can have disproportionate impact by safeguarding data and software used by or for hundreds, thousands, or even millions of end users.

The project provided training opportunities for multiple graduate students. The student fieldworkers had the opportunity to work in real software development companies and apply their skills to help the company improve their products' security -- a highly valuable part of their PhD program. Moreover, our ethnographic work provides an opportunity for company developers to learn more about software security in real context. This will help their professional development and at the same time contribute to solving the problem.
